comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
The `Undefined` policy is the same as `Restricted` by default, to my knowledge. Setting the policy to undefined is requesting the same behaviour as default, which is the no-scripts-allowed behaviour.

If you want to run scripts you need to set it to `Unrestricted` or `RemoteSigned` (or `AllSigned` if you only want to allow signed scripts from trusted providers to run).

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: @grooveasylum You are selecting yes, the color just tells you what the default is.  Check the output of this: `Get-ExecutionPolicy -List`.  If `CurrentUser` is set, that'll take precedence over `LocalMachine`.  If `MachinePolicy` or `UserPolicy` is set, then it's set via GPO and it can't be changed (without getting your org to change the GPO).
